Cumin oil:
Toast  T. cumin seeds in a dry skillet until fragrant
column4: a couple minutes over medium heat. Crush the toasted cumin with a mortar and pestle -\n a spice grinder
column5: knife\n whatever you've got. Back to the skillet: add  extra-virgin olive oil to the skillet
column6:
let it heat up and add the crushed cumin seeds along with a few pinches of salt. Remove from heat and let sit for 
  minutes. 
Cumin croutons:
Preheat the oven to  degrees. Cut a small loaf of rye bread into crouton-sized cubes. In a medium bowl toss a couple handfuls of the rye cubes with the cumin oil until they are nicely coated. Place on a baking sheet in the oven for  minutes
 so - until the croutons are crisp and starting to brown."

Add-ins: When delicata squash as still in season - I cube and roast it to top this risotto. In the photo above you'll also see I used some chopped chives and a generous drizzle of curried brown butter made from simply adding a bit of curry powder to a skillet of butter I'd browned over medium heat. But now that we are smack in the middle of spring
column5: I've been trading out the squash for chopped asparagus and  peas - adding them to the pot in the last few minutes."

column4: cut into  -inch segments\n pound /  oz /  g stuffed pasta (ravioli

Get a big pot of water started - you are going to want to bring it to a boil. 
While the water is heating
column7: make the sauce. Heat the oil in a small saucepan over medium heat. Add the garlic
column13: \n until the spices are toasted and fragrant. Transfer this mixture to a medium mixing bowl and stir in the water
column17: and  teaspoon of salt. Taste and adjust to your liking - you most likely will need a bit more salt. Set aside.\nSalt the pot of water generously
column20: and green beans. Boil just  seconds
column21: and quickly fish out with a slotted spoon. Run the vegetables under cold water to stop cooking. Drain well and set aside in a large mixing bowl.\nReturn the water to a boil and add the pasta. Cook until al dente
column22: then drain and run under cold water. Really try to shake off any extra water
column23: then add to the vegetables. Add the tomatoes
column24: and toss gently. You can toss with half of the sauce at this point
column25:
serve the salad with dollops of the sauce on top - to be tossed at the table. It's prettier this way. Sprinkle with the basil/cilantro (and basil flowers if you have them) and serve. Serve the extra sauce on the side - any leftover makes a good dip later in the week.
Adapted from the Pasta Salad with Tangy Sesame-Yogurt Sauce in Peter Berley's The Modern Vegetarian Kitchen.

You can make the crust using the quick and popular food processor technique. BUT I always make it by hand

depending on how the dough is feeling. The pie in the photo was x.
Berry Pie Filling

 brown sugar

 wwp)

 sprigs thyme (prefer. lemon thyme) ~  t.
 pounds of berries

(see head notes)

  butter

column10: for sprinkling\nPreheat your oven to F / C
column11: with a rack in the bottom third. Roll out your pie crust - top and bottom - on a flour dusted counter. I tend to work the edges a bit first (particularly if I'm getting cracks) - roll and turn
column13: dusting with flour when necessary. Flip once\n twice. Work quickly and keep the dough moving. Place between unbleached parchment paper\n Silpats
column14: and refrigerate while you make the filling. If you're nervous about rolling out the crust
column15: have a look at the second part of Melissa Clark's video. See how she's not super fussy? Channel some of that. If you need an extra confidence booster
column16: read this. It's o.k. if your dough doesn't roll out into a perfect circle - you can patch and pinch later if needed. Just shoot for \n -inch inch rounds.\nMake the filling by combining the sugar
column20: and thyme in large mixing bowl. Add the berries
column21: and toss gently until well combined. Set aside.\nLine a \n -inch pie plate with the bottom piece of pie dough. Guide it into place without stretching. You want about an inch of dough extending past the rim of the pie plate
column22: trim a bit with scissors\n a sharp knife if needed.\nFill the crust with the berries
column24: and dot with the butter. Brush the rim of the bottom crust with a bit of egg wash
column25: then top with the other piece of pie crust. Trim the top crust a bit if needed
column26: then press the top and bottom crusts together at the edges. Working around the rim
column27: tuck the overhanging dough under itself
column28: and crimp with a fork\n flute using your fingers (see picture up above). Brush the crust with more of the egg wash
column29: cut a few slits into the top
column30: and place in the oven for about  minutes - until the crust is deeply golden. Check your pie regularly after  minutes. If you need to foil the edges of the pie - pull it out and do so - this way the edges wont get too dark and dry. I don't have to foil in my oven for this pie
column32: but your oven might be a bit different. I also sprinkle with large-grain sugar about  minutes in - for a little extra crunch and sweetness. Let cool a bit
column33:
slice and serve.
